sentences.sentence: But what a surprise!
As he passed through the gate of the city, the guards bowed down to( 屈身致意 ) him with respect, and said, “How beautiful is our lord!”
And a crowd( 人群 ) of citizens followed him, and shouted, “There is no one else as beautiful in the whole world!”
The Star-Child cried, and said to himself, “They are playing a joke on( 开玩笑 ) me, and laughing at me behind my back because I am so ugly.”
The crowd( 人群 ) of people was so large, that he lost his way, and found himself at last in a great square, where there was the King’s palace.
The gate of the palace opened, and the priests( 神父 ) and the officials( 官员 ) of the city ran out to meet him.
They bowed( 鞠躬 ) before him, and then they said, “You are our lord, and the son of our King, and we have been waiting for you.”
The Star-Child answered them and said, “I am no king’s son, but the child of a poor beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ).
And how can you say that I am beautiful, when I know I am terrible to look at?”
Then the Star-Child noticed the soldier( 士兵 ) who had sold him to be a slave( 奴隶 ), and who had silver flowers on his armor( 盔甲 ).
The soldier( 士兵 ) held up his shield( 盾牌 ), which was like a mirror( 镜子 ), and he said, “How can my lord say that he is not beautiful?”
The Star-Child looked at the shield( 盾牌 ), and was again greatly surprised!
His face was as beautiful as it had been before, and no longer ugly like a toad( 懒蛤蟆 ), and his body was no longer disgusting( 令人厌恶的 ) like a snake’s.
The priests( 神父 ) and the officials( 官员 ) bowed down( 跪拜 ) and said to him, “We have long known that on this day our new King would come to us.
Therefore, let our lord take this crown( 王冠 ) and this scepter( 权杖 ), and become our new King.”
But he said to them, “I am not worthy of this honor( 头衔 ), because I sent away my own mother.
I cannot rest until I find her, and she has given me her forgiveness( 原谅 ).
Therefore, let me go, for I must wander( 流浪 ) again over the whole world.
I cannot stay here, and I cannot be your king.”
And as he spoke he turned his face from them toward the street that led to the gate of the city.
And he was surprised once more, because in the crowd( 人群 ) of people he saw the beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ) who was his mother.
And at her side stood the beggar( 乞丐 ) to whom he had given the three pieces of gold.
A cry of joy( 喜悦 ) broke from his lips( 嘴唇 ), and he ran over to them.
He bowed down( 俯身 ) and kissed the wounds( 伤口 ) on his mother’s feet, and wet them with his tears( 眼泪 ).
He bowed( 低下 ) his head in the dust( 尘埃 ), and cried, like someone whose heart might break.
And he said to her: “Mother, I chased( 赶走 ) you away because I was proud. Please give me your forgiveness( 原谅 ).”
But the beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ) did not answer him.
He reached out his hands, and held the feet of the beggar( 乞丐 ).
And he said to him: “Three times I gave you my gold. Please tell my mother to speak to me once.”
But the beggar( 乞丐 ) did not answer him.
The Star-Child cried again and said: “Mother, my suffering( 苦难 ) is greater than I can take.
Give me your forgiveness( 原谅 ), and let me go back to the forest.”
The beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ) put her hand on his head, and said to him, “Rise!”
And the beggar( 乞丐 ) put his hand on his head too, and said the same thing. “Rise!”
The Star-Child stood up.
And when he looked at the two people in front of him again, he saw that they had changed.
They were no longer beggars( 乞丐 ). They were a King and a Queen.
The Queen looked at the Star-Child and said to him, “This man in front of you who you gave your gold to is your father, the King.”
The Star-Child looked at his father, the King.
And the King said, “This is your mother whose feet you have washed with your tears( 眼泪 ).”
And then his mother and father held him in their arms and kissed him, and brought him into the palace.
They gave him fine clothes, and set the crown( 王冠 ) on his head, and the scepter( 权杖 ) in his hand.
He ruled over the city that stood by the river, and was its King.
He was a very fair and kind king, except to the Magician, whom he sent out of the city.
He sent the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ) and his wife many expensive gifts, and brought their children to stay in his palace.
He was never again cruel( 残忍的 ) to animals or men, and taught love and kindness to all the people in his kingdom.
To the poor he gave bread, and to the sick he gave medicine, and there was peace and plenty in the land.
Yet he did not rule for long, because he had suffered( 受苦 ) too greatly before becoming King, and after three years he died.
And the King who came after him was very cruel( 残暴的 ).
